I 4 I THE ANCIENT ESSE-NES. —ORIGIN OF Till ORDER. Essx~tx from the hebrew r~oot, ~ (Esan, to be strong), ~ (Essene) because they exhibited strength of mind, in enduring suffering, and in subduing the passions; the Essenes ~ were an order cf the Jews, and the fact that they developed themselves gradually, and at ~rst imperceptibly, through intensifying the prevalent religious doc - trines, i~enders it impossible to say precisely K at whtt timo they were detached from the general body. Josophus, however, speaks of them as existing in the days of Jonathan the Maccab~an, B.c. 143 (Ant. xiii. 5—9); he also mentions an Es~ene who delivered a prophecy in the reign of Ai istobulus I., B.~ M(C I UCcjJhIi& —Kuto.

Both Philo and Josephus mention thoni as being very numerous at this time. — They were divided into two classes —the fir~ devoting themselves to a life of eon - templation, and studying the mysteries of nature and revelation; the second eligag - ing in some daily handicraft. They were ruled by a Rabban * assisted by a Rabbi and a IRab, who were chosen by the whole body. In cases of trial, however, a majority wa~ reqiiircd to constitute a tribunal, and the brother who walked disorderly wa~ •flabbiia, from the H8brew ~, mastur. Rabbi, ‘ “ “ ~ a t6acher. Rab. “ “ “ ~ assistant teaohu ‘I? I 4 7 exeominun, .~ated; yet he was not regarded as an enemy, but was adnonished as a brother, and usually received back, after due repentance. They divided the twenty-four hours hAn three parts: a portion of which wa~ devot - ed to the service of God and the relief of the needy and distressed, a portion to their usual avocations, and a portion for refresh. inent and sleep. They rose at early dawn and offered up the national prayer for the return of the light of day, after which they betook them - selves to their respective vocations and engagements, under the superintendence oL the Rabbans and Overseers. At the sixth hour, or twelve o’clock, the labor of the forenoon terminated, and all reassembled. bathed in cold water, after which they put on their white garmnonts, entered their refectory with as much solemnity as if it were the Holy Temple, and sat dow-n togethew in mysterious silence to the common meal, When seated, the priest invoked G )d’s bless - ~ng upon we repast, after ~vlmi-li the bakei

At the conclusion of ,the n~eal the prie~l offered up thanks to the Bountiful Supplier of all our wants. This was the signal of their dismissal, when they withdrew, pni off their white garments, and resumed labor again until the eleventh hour (or five o’clock, as we reckon time). On the Sabbath they assembled in the synagogues, where they were seated according to their age, tho younger sitting below the elder in becom - ing attire, and listening with due attention Then one takes up the Sacred Volume and reads a portion, whilst a Rabbi expounds. But as they were completely esoteric iii their doctrines, they omitted the most mys. terious portions, whieh were only taught in the Tladoth,* or place of secret meeting9. As a sect they were distinguished by a~ aspiration after ~)urity, and, like the Cha - uidim of earlier times, were confounded in • Hadoth, from the Hebrew ~ a place of seciet trit-eting, or meeting by appointmez~t. mire popular estimation -with the great body of the zealous observers of the law. The growth of Essenism was a natural result of the religious feeling which was called out by the circumstances of the Greek domin - ion, and it is easy to trace the process by which it was matured. From the Maccab~uan age there was a continuous effort among the stricter Jews to attain au absolute standard of IHoliness - Each class of devotees was looked upon as practically impure by their successors, who carm-ied the - laws of purity still further; and the Essenes stood at the extreme limit of the mystic asceticism, which was thus gr~aaHy reduced to shape. As an Order they were distinguished by the following principles and observ- ances A hove of truth and sobriety; ‘ove to God and man, made manifest by religious zeal and kindly acts towards each othcr; always aiding the needy—and ¶0 this cud tney had st~waris in every place where ~oy ~we1t to supply needy bredirei~

He then remained iim a state of probation and trial for one year, during which time, although he lived ac eording to their customs, he was not ad mitted to their secret meetings. At the termination of this period he was advanced to the second rank, with its consequoiil rights and privileges; but he was not ad - mitted to full fellowship with them until after another year of probation, when, if stil found worthy, he was advanced to the third rank, and invested with all of the sigmis,’ pass-words, and privileges c ~ the (Jider. On his admission he ¶vas requi cd t4 4 tAke upon himself a solemn oath or ob ligation, the heads of which were as fol. lows To exercise piety towards God and justice towards men; to shun the wicked and ema - li~te the good; to show fidelity and obedience to those in authority; to be a lover of truth and a reprover of falsehood; to keep his hands clean from theft, and his soul from un - lawful gains; to conceal’ nothing from the Order, nor disclose any of their secrets to any one in any other mauner than he receiv - ed them himself; and, lastly, to carefully guard and preserve the Sacred Books and Symbols belonging to the Order.
